customData.content: 71-year-old male with stage 1 COPD, heavy smoker, presented to the emergency room with 2-week diffuse abdominal pain, no nausea, vomiting, GI transit disturbances, or changes in stool appearance, 13 kg weight loss over the past year, and chronic nonproductive cough.

HPI.summary: 71-year-old male presented with 2-week diffuse abdominal pain, no nausea, vomiting, GI transit disturbances, or changes in stool appearance, 13 kg weight loss over the past year, and chronic nonproductive cough.

customData.content: Physical examination revealed hypophonesis in the left upper pulmonary quadrant and acropachy in the upper extremities. Complete blood count and serum chemistry showed no abnormalities. Chest X-ray showed a paramediastinal mass in the left upper lobe with homogeneous density and regular edges. Admitted for further evaluation.

physical_exam.finding: hypophonesis in the left upper pulmonary quadrant

imaging.finding: paramediastinal mass in the left upper lobe with homogeneous density and regular edges

customData.content: Worsening abdominal pain, bloating, vomiting, GI transit disturbances progressing to complete GI transit stoppage, and significant abdominal distention. Physical examination showed a distended, hyperresonant abdomen, without rebound tenderness or peritoneal irritation signs. A nasogastric tube was placed.

HPI.summary: Worsening abdominal pain, bloating, vomiting, GI transit disturbances progressing to complete GI transit stoppage, and significant abdominal distention.

customData.content: Emergency abdominal CT scan showed a 7 cm lesion located in the posterior apical segment of the left upper lobe in a paramediastinal situation, in close contact with the superior margin of the oblique fissure, main left pulmonary artery, and left margin of the aortic arch (3 cm).

imaging.finding: 7 cm lesion located in the posterior apical segment of the left upper lobe in a paramediastinal situation, in close contact with the superior margin of the oblique fissure, main left pulmonary artery, and left margin of the aortic arch

customData.content: Abdominal CT scan showed a 7 cm hypervascular lesion of neoplastic appearance in the ileocecal junction, along with adenopathies in the ileocolic, subcarinal, mediastinal, and pulmonary hilum territories.

imaging.finding: 7 cm hypervascular lesion of neoplastic appearance

customData.content: Emergency right hemicolectomy was performed with intraoperative findings of an ileocecal mass strongly adhered to the right parietocolic gutter, as well as several adenopathies along the ileocolonic axis, free abdominal fluid, and proximal distension of the small bowel.

imaging.finding: strongly adhered to the right parietocolic gutter

HPI.summary: proximal distension of the small bowel

data.content: Patient transitioned from initial presentation to physical examination and initial imaging. Chest X-ray showed a paramediastinal mass in the left upper lobe with homogeneous density and regular edges.

Patient's abdominal pain worsened, with new symptoms of bloating, vomiting, GI transit disturbances progressing to complete GI transit stoppage, and significant abdominal distention. A nasogastric tube was placed.

Emergency abdominal CT scan was performed to investigate the cause of the abdominal symptoms. CT scan showed a 7 cm lesion located in the posterior apical segment of the left upper lobe in a paramediastinal situation, in close contact with the superior margin of the oblique fissure, main left pulmonary artery, and left margin of the aortic arch (3 cm).

Abdominal CT scan revealed a 7 cm hypervascular lesion of neoplastic appearance in the ileocecal junction, along with adenopathies in the ileocolic, subcarinal, mediastinal, and pulmonary hilum territories.

Emergency right hemicolectomy was performed due to the ileocecal mass. Intraoperative findings included the mass strongly adhered to the right parietocolic gutter, adenopathies along the ileocolonic axis, free abdominal fluid, and proximal distension of the small bowel.
